Q: NodeJS and Mongo line who's online A:

The performance problem you’re hitting isn’t really MongoDB vs Redis — it’s the data model.

What’s expensive here is treating “online” as a piece of state you persist and mutate on every connect/disconnect. In real systems, those events happen far more often than people expect (tab closes, reconnects, network hiccups), which turns presence into a write-heavy workload and makes counts unreliable.

A more scalable approach is to stop storing “online users” as records and instead model presence as a session-level signal.

In practice that means:

  • treat each connection (tab/device/client) as its own session

  • record lightweight heartbeats or activity timestamps per session

  • derive “online” from how recently a signal was observed, not from connect/disconnect events

  • let sessions expire via TTL instead of explicitly writing offline state

With that model, “online users” becomes a derived query, not a mutable counter. You can keep the hot presence data in memory or Redis, and only persist summaries if you actually need them. MongoDB stops being part of the real-time loop.

This doesn’t make presence perfectly certain, but it makes it truthful and stable. Brief disconnects, tab closes, and reconnects stop causing flapping or expensive writes, and your system scales with concurrent sessions instead of raw events.

If you want a deeper breakdown of this session-first, signal-based approach (and why storing online state directly breaks down), this write-up explains the pattern in detail:

https://www.joegalaxy.net/docs/whos-online-api

Q: Codeigniter 2.1 - MySQL and regexp A:

I don't think you need RegExp here - LIKE would be just fine. If your date is stored as timestamp, you should do FROM_UNIXTIME($col) LIKE '2012-06-11'

EDIT: Although, it is not efficient. Better way is to compare timestamp as an integer:

$col >= UNIX_TIMESTAMP('2012-06-11 00:00:00') AND $col < UNIX_TIMESTAMP('2012-06-12 00:00:00')
